PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN STOCK NEWS: Harbour Energy makes offer for Santos (STO AT); WTI crude fell around 3% and gold rose 1.4%
content:
AUSTRALIA

Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA AT)
- APRA found CBA at fault regarding loan data, while it also noted that Co. risks were high and increasing, according to memo for the board. (AFR)

Santos (STO AT)
- Harbour Energy was said to have reapproached the Co. and made a AUD 6.50/Shr offer vs. last close AUD 5.07/Shr. (AFR)

Virgin Australia (VAH AT)
- Co. reportedly faces uncertainty as shareholder Etihad is said to considering exiting its stake. (The Australian)

Vocus Communications (VOC AT)
- Brookfield is preparing to make an offer for the Co.’s New Zealand Assets. (Newswires)

Wesfarmers (WES AT)
- Co. is said to have hired Lazard to search for buyers of Co.’s Homebase chain in UK. (The Australian)

Westpac (WBC AT)
- Co. reached agreement with Assembly Payments on integration of merchant terminals with point of sale software to lower costs of re-entering data. (AFR)

Basic Materials / Energy
- Spot gold rose 1.4%.
- WTI crude futures fell around 3% to below USD 63/bbl.

 

JAPAN

Disco Corp (6146 JT)
- Co. Q4 prelim. oper. profit JPY 7.8bln vs. Exp. JPY 8.9bln. (Newswires)

Itochu (8001 JT)
- Co. raises stake in Vietnam textile firm Vinatex to around 15% from 5%. (Nikkei)

J Front Retailing (3086 JT)
- Co. March department store sales rose 4.2% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal (5401 JT)
- ArcelorMittal (MT NA) which is attempting a joint acquisition with Nippon Steel and Sumitomo Metal has submitted a new bid for Essar Steel. (Nikkei)

Welcia Holdings (3141 JT)
- Co. FY17 oper. profit may have increased 16% Y/Y to JPY 28bln. (Nikkei)

Other News
- Japan's GPIF moves into high-yield bond trading from this month as revised portfolio rules now permit the public pension fund to invest in Japanese bonds with BB or lower ratings. (Nikkei)
- Japan ruling parties have agreed on maximum of 3 casino resorts, but have not agreed yet regarding casino entry fees. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

LG Electronics (032640 KS)
- Co. is likely to include an advanced LCD in its latest G7 smartphone, as well as ‘notch design’ and AI switch. (Newswires)

Orion Holdings (001800 SK)
- Co. wins suit in Vietnam against firm using its Choco Pie trademark. (Newswires)

Automakers
- South Korean automakers’ sales rose 0.7% Y/Y during March. (Yonhap)

Data Recap
- South Korean CPI (Mar) M/M -0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.8%). (Newswires)
- South Korean CPI (Mar) Y/Y 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.4% (Prev. 1.4%)
- South Korean Core CPI (Mar) Y/Y 1.3% (Prev. 1.2%)

ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights Include RBA Rate Decision, Australian AiG and CBA PMIs, 10yr JGB Auction and Fed's Kashkari Speech
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China is said to plan further trade retaliations if the US acts obstinately, according to China state media reports. (Newswires)
 

FX

The DXY starts the Month/quarter slightly lower, mainly hit by USDJPY, which slid to 105.65 as risk sentiment was hit by China’s trade war escalation; there was also modest buying after the March ISM non-manufacturing survey fell short of expectations. The yen largely ignored the latest Tankan survey, released overnight. The EUR traded a narrow range, finding its way back to the 1.23 handle as we head into Asia, having seen 1.2280 as stocks dropped near the open. GBP was up against the USD and EUR, gapping higher at Sunday’s open after it was reported that the UK has a proposal to resolve the Irish border issue; the plan would see the UK act as an 'external frontier' for the EU, collecting tariffs and carrying out other checks at the border, and will be discussed with EU officials later this month. CAD and MXN were initially resilient to Trump’s NAFTA threats on Twitter, though both have succumbed to USD strength as commodity FX and EMs are generally weaker against the buck; the CAD has made its way back up to the top end of the recent 1.2850-1.2950 range. AUD, meanwhile, is consolidating around the 0.7650 level ahead of this week’s RBA (expected unchanged).
 

COMMODITIES

WTI was horizontal above $65.00 as NY traders returned from the long-weekend; fears of escalating Trade Wars injected a risk-off tone to Monday trade, which saw equities – and subsequently crude – under pressure. The risk-off tone was helped by pre-market news that Russia reported that March output rose to 10.97mln BPD, up from February’s 10.95mln, making Russia the largest crude producer, overtaking the US. The news didn’t immediately move the crude complex, perhaps because European markets were shut due to Bank Holiday. Additionally, over the weekend, Bahrain announced it made the largest oil discovery in its history, which eclipses its current reserves (estimated to be up to 200mln bbls), adding to the global oversupply narrative. More details are expected this week. This week, analysts expect to see crude stocks build by 1.7mln barrels (which would be the second consecutive build), distillate stocks are seen drawing 500k bbls, and gasoline stocks are seen drawing 1.5mln bbls. WTI futures (June) settled USD 1.69 lower at USD 63.18 per barrel; Brent (June) settled USD 1.70 lower at USD 67.64/bbl

Russia Energy minister Novak said Russia is committed to reaching balance on global oil market. (Newswires)


US

White House Trade Adviser Navarro said markets should relax and that the economy is performing well, while also stated they need to be hopeful regarding NAFTA negotiations. Furthermore, Navarro added that China is stealing US stuff but does not believe US and China will pursue an ' action-response' escalation of trade dispute. (Newswires)

US President Trump said to push for a NAFTA deal 'in principle' within a fortnight, while there were also reports of speculation that a NAFTA deal could be announced at the Summits of Americas on April 13th-14th. (Newswires)

US Markit Manufacturing PMI (Mar F): 55.6 (Exp. 55.7; Flash 55.7; Prev. 55.3). (Newswires)
US ISM Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 59.3 vs. Exp. 60.1 (Prev. 60.8)
US Construction Spending (Feb) M/M 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.0%)


MARKET RECAP

With Europe, UK, Australia, New Zealand and Canada on a market holiday, liquidity was thin, and price action was choppy, amid the risk-off tone begotten by a perceived escalation of Trade Wars by China overnight, where it announced it would apply tariffs of up to 25% on imports of US pork, wine, and nuts (many analysts have downplayed the impact, though the likes of Tyson Foods were hit on the news). Equity futures were traversing sideways pre-market in negative territory, but it was only just before the cash open when selling intensified as NY traders returned from the long-weekend. All sectors were red, but tech was a notable underperformer with Amazon pressuring equities after Trump’s antagonistic tweeting, while consumer discretionary was also whacked. Technical selling pressure entered after the SPX fell below its 200dma around 2590, before stabilising around 2560 (the index closes beneath its 200dma ending a 448-day run). Tesla’s woes helped dragged the Nasdaq lower, helping the Composite to join the SPX and DJIA in technical correction territory. SPX -2.3% at 2580, DJIA -2.0% at 23,629, NDX -2.9% at 6391.

The TPLEX begins the new month/quarter bid, with the complex fulfilling its role as a safe-haven amid the stock slide. But it is worth keeping these moves in context; volume was naturally thinner in holiday trading conditions, and T-Note futures settle a mere four ticks higher (despite 10-year yields falling to 2.7170%, the lowest since early February. Major curve spreads saw only modest flattening (between 0.5bps to 2bps), and in the pre-market – before the stocks’ slide – the curve was bear-steepening.

subject: US MARKET WRAP: Stocks slammed on trade war escalation fears
content:
* SNAPSHOT: Equities down, DXY down, Treasuries up, crude down, gold up.
* REAR-VIEW: China to put tariffs on US pork, fruit, nuts; ISM manufacturing misses.
* AHEAD: Kashkari (non-voter, Monday after market); Fed chair Powell (Friday); NFP (Friday).

EQUITIES: SPX -2.3% at 2580, DJIA -2.0% at 23,629, NDX -2.9% at 6391; SECTORS: Utilities -1.2%, Telecoms -1.6%, Energy -2.5%, Healthcare -2.6%, Consumer non-cyclicals -2.6%, Financials -2.6%, Materials -2.7%, Industrials -2.7%, Tech -3.0%, Consumer Cyclicals -3.3%
With Europe, UK, Australia, New Zealand and Canada on a market holiday, liquidity was thin, and price action was choppy, amid the risk-off tone begotten by a perceived escalation of Trade Wars by China overnight, where it announced it would apply tariffs of up to 25% on imports of US pork, wine, and nuts (many analysts have downplayed the impact, though the likes of Tyson Foods were hit on the news). Equity futures were traversing sideways pre-market in negative territory, but it was only just before the cash open when selling intensified as NY traders returned from the long-weekend. All sectors were red, but tech was a notable underperformer with Amazon pressuring equities after Trump’s antagonistic tweeting, while consumer discretionary was also whacked. Technical selling pressure entered after the SPX fell below its 200dma around 2590, before stabilising around 2560 (the index closes beneath its 200dma ending a 448-day run). Tesla’s woes helped dragged the Nasdaq lower, helping the Composite to join the SPX and DJIA in technical correction territory.

TREASURIES: US 10-Year T-Note futures settle 4 ticks higher at 121-08+
The TPLEX begins the new month/quarter bid, with the complex fulfilling its role as a safe-haven amid the stock slide. But it is worth keeping these moves in context; volume was naturally thinner in holiday trading conditions, and T-Note futures settle a mere four ticks higher (despite 10-year yields falling to 2.7170%, the lowest since early February. Major curve spreads saw only modest flattening (between 0.5bps to 2bps), and in the pre-market – before the stocks’ slide – the curve was bear-steepening.

FOREX: DXY -0.1% heading into APAC trade
The DXY starts the Month/quarter slightly lower, mainly hit by USDJPY, which slid to 105.65 as risk sentiment was hit by China’s trade war escalation; there was also modest buying after the March ISM non-manufacturing survey fell short of expectations. The yen largely ignored the latest Tankan survey, released overnight. The EUR traded a narrow range, finding its way back to the 1.23 handle as we head into Asia, having seen 1.2280 as stocks dropped near the open. GBP was up against the USD and EUR, gapping higher at Sunday’s open after it was reported that the UK has a proposal to resolve the Irish border issue; the plan would see the UK act as an 'external frontier' for the EU, collecting tariffs and carrying out other checks at the border, and will be discussed with EU officials later this month. CAD and MXN were initially resilient to Trump’s NAFTA threats on Twitter, though both have succumbed to USD strength as commodity FX and EMs are generally weaker against the buck; the CAD has made its way back up to the top end of the recent 1.2850-1.2950 range. AUD, meanwhile, is consolidating around the 0.7650 level ahead of this week’s RBA (expected unchanged).

CRUDE: WTI futures (June) settle USD 1.69 lower at USD 63.18 per barrel; Brent (June) settles $1.70 lower at $67.64/bbl
WTI was horizontal above $65.00 as NY traders returned from the long-weekend; fears of escalating Trade Wars injected a risk-off tone to Monday trade, which saw equities – and subsequently crude – under pressure. The risk-off tone was helped by pre-market news that Russia reported that March output rose to 10.97mln BPD, up from February’s 10.95mln, making Russia the largest crude producer, overtaking the US. The news didn’t immediately move the crude complex, perhaps because European markets were shut due to Bank Holiday. Additionally, over the weekend, Bahrain announced it made the largest oil discovery in its history, which eclipses its current reserves (estimated to be up to 200mln bbls), adding to the global oversupply narrative. More details are expected this week. This week, analysts expect to see crude stocks build by 1.7mln barrels (which would be the second consecutive build), distillate stocks are seen drawing 500k bbls, and gasoline stocks are seen drawing 1.5mln bbls.

subject: DAILY US EQUITY OPENING NEWS - Walmart (WMT)/Humana (HUM) – The retail giant is in early level talks with Humana about closer ties and possibly an acquisition.
content:
2nd April 2018

EARNINGS

DJIA

  • Boeing (BA) - Saudi Arabian Military Industries and Boeing signed a Memorandum of Agreement to develop a new joint venture aiming to localise more than 55% of the MRO services for fixed and rotary-wing military aircraft in Saudi Arabia. (Newswires)
  • Walmart (WMT)/Humana (HUM) – The retail giant is in early level talks with Humana about closer ties and possibly an acquisition.  Separately, the company has opened its first small, high tech store in China. (Newswires)
  • Nike (NKE) – The athletic apparel co. is in the process of trying to address and correct a “boys club” culture. (WSJ)
  • Coca Cola (KO) – The drinks manufacturer is suing the Internal Revenue Service over a USD 3.3bln bill for back taxes arguing recently approved rights to make and sell coke products in foreign countries. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • AT&T (T) / Time Warner (TWX) – 12% of subscribers would quit their cable or satellite companies if Time Warner’s Turner networks were no longer available, according to a Massachusetts Institute of Technology marketing professor. (Newswires)  
  • FirstEnergy (FE) – The co.’s subsidiaries and FirstEnergy Nuclear Operating have filed voluntary petitions under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code with the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in the Northern District of Ohio in Akron. (Newswires)
  • General Motors (GM) – The South Korean unit has proposed suspending one of two shifts at a plant near Seoul, showing increased uncertainty about the fate of the factory. (Newswires)
  • PG&E (PCG) – The co. has announced that it is acting to pass along approximately USD 450Mln in annual tax savings to its customers. (Newswires)
  • Under Amour (UAA) – The sports retailer informed its MyFitnessPal app users of a data breach with 150 million users affected. (CNBC)

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon (AMZN) - Donald Trump criticized Amazon again, with some tweets on Saturday morning stating, among other things, that “Amazon must pay real costs (and taxes) now!”.  Separately, the co. is shutting down its TenMarks online math and writing learning service after the 2018-2019 school year. (Newswires)
  • Casino Names (WYNN, LVS, MGM) – Macau gambling revenue was up 22% in March y/y. (CNBC)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – The automaker has said that the auto pilot was involved in the fatal crash. Separately, it is recalling over 120,000 Model S cars over power steering concerns. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Abiomed (ABMD) – The co. has named Todd Trapp as its CFO. Separately, it has received FDA approval for Impella CP with Smart Assistance. (Newswires)
  • Almost Family (AFAM) / LHC Group (LHCG) – The co. has announced the completion of a merger with Almost Family. (Newswires)
  • Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) – The co. will not pay a dividend for Q1,2 & 3 of FY18. (Newswires)
  • Alibaba (BABA) – The Chinese retail giant will buy the part of China food delivery platform Ele.me that it does not already own. (Currently owns roughly 23%). (CNBC)
  • Alkermes (ALKS) / Intra-Cellular (ITCI) – The co. has announced the FDA’s refusal to file letter received for its new drug ALKS 5461 for treatment of major depressive disorder in patients with an inadequate response to standard antidepressant therapies. STAT's Adam Feuerstein tweeted following the Alkermes news, "Anyone confident in $ITCI now? I wouldn't be.". (Newswires)
  • Myriad Genetics (MYGN) – The co. has announced that the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare has granted manufacturing and marketing approval for Myriad's BRACAnalysis Diagnostic System. (Newswires)
  • Nextera Energy Partners (NEP) – The co. is to sell its Canadian operating portfolio to Canada Pension Plan Investment Board for USD 741mln. (Newswires)
  • Snap (SNAP) – In March, the co. cut 7% of its global workforce, according to a regulatory filing. (CNBC)
  • Sonoco Products (SON) – The co. announced the start of Robert Tiede's tenure as the new President and CEO of Sonoco. (Newswires)
  • Twitter (TWTR) – Price Target cut to USD 20.00 at Pivotal research. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

  • ADP (ADP) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM SECTOR PERFORM AT RBC CAPITAL

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia began the new fiscal year positive, but with gains capped amid mixed Chinese data and market closures
content: Asia equity markets were mostly higher but with gains contained amid a holiday-quietened tone (Australia, New Zealand, Hong Kong, EU and UK are all closed) and as participants digested several key data releases including mostly better than expected Chinese PMI figures. Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) was positive as the index shrugged off a disappointing BoJ Tankan where large manufacturers’ sentiment deteriorated for the first time in 2 years and large industry numbers mostly missed forecasts, as the data also showed a strong all industry capex component and increased confidence across smaller businesses. Elsewhere, KOSPI (+0.2%) was also higher amid the improved geopolitical climate in the Korean peninsula, while Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) was underpinned after better than expected Chinese Official Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI data over the weekend. Conversely, the Caixin Manufacturing PMI release was less inspiring and fell short of estimates while China also confirmed tariffs on US products in retaliation to US protectionist measures on steel and aluminium, which in turn capped advances in the mainland. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful with price action range-bound amid gains in riskier assets as well as an unchanged BoJ Rinban announcement.

subject: Bajaj Auto (BJAUT IS) March sales 334.3K units vs. Prev. 272.2K units Y/Y
PRE-MARKET INDIAN STOCK NEWS: Tata Power (TPWR IS) is to offload defence business to Tata Advanced Systems in INR 22.3bln deal
content:
ICICI Bank (ICICIBC IS)
- CBI is soon to examine Co. CEO regarding the loan case involving Videocon Group’s Dhoot which occurred around 10 years ago. (ET)

Maruti Suzuki (MSIL IS)
- Co. March sales rose 14.9% Y/Y to 160.6K units. (Newswires)

Tata Power (TPWR IS)
 Co. is to offload defence business to Tata Advanced Systems in INR 22.3bln deal. (Moneycontrol)

subject: Alibaba (BABA) to acquire 57% stake in Ele.Me it doesn't own

China to resume subsidies for electric vehicles with Korean batteries soon
ASIA-PAC MID SESSION UPDATE: Asia begins the week higher but with gains contained amid holiday closures
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly higher but with gains contained amid a holiday-quietened tone (Australia, New Zealand, Hong Kong, EU and UK are all closed) and as participants digest several key data releases including mostly better than expected Chinese PMI figures. Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) is positive as the index shrugs off a disappointing BoJ Tankan where large manufacturers’ sentiment deteriorated for the first time in 2 years and large industry numbers missed forecasts, as the data also showed strong all industry capex and increased confidence across smaller businesses. Elsewhere, KOSPI (+0.3%) is also positive amid the improved geopolitical climate in the Korean peninsula, while Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) also gains after better than expected Chinese Official Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI data over the weekend. Conversely, the Caixin Manufacturing PMI release was less inspiring and fell short of estimates while China also confirmed tariffs on US products in retaliation to US protectionist measures on steel and aluminium, which in turn has capped advances in the mainland.

FX markets are uneventful due to the lack of participants for the start of the week. Nonetheless, the greenback is slightly subdued with the DXY slipping back below the 90.00 level to provide some respite for EUR/USD and GBP/USD from the prior week’s losses. Elsewhere, antipodeans are indecisive as markets digest the mixed Chinese PMI data releases, while KRW outperforms amongst the EM currencies and reached its strongest since October 2014 as the softer stance from North Korea continues to bode well for the currency as the latest reports stated North Korean Leader Kim attended a K-Pop concert in Pyongyang.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are uneventful with price action range-bound amid gains in riskier assets as well as an unchanged BoJ Rinban announcement.

content:
Bank of China (3988 HK / 601988CH)
- Co. FY net CNY 172.4bln vs. Exp. CNY 167.4bln, oper. rev. CNY 483.8bln vs. Prev. CNY 485.7bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Casino Names
- Macau Gaming Revenue for March rose 22.2% Y/Y to MOP 25.9B vs. Exp. 16.6% increase. (Newswires)

Steel Names
- China’s Handan city has ordered steel mills to reduce steel output by 25%. (Newswires)

Other News
- China imposed tariffs of between 15% and 25% on imports of 128 different products from the US including pork, nuts, wine and fruits as a response to the US tariffs on steel and aluminium. (Newswires/Twitter)
- CSRC announces pilot scheme to encourage qualified firms in chosen sectors to float on the domestic stock exchanges, while it targets overseas-listed large Chinese tech firms to list at home through share issuances or Chinese Depositary Receipts. (Newswires)

Data Recap

- Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 54.6 vs. Exp. 54.5 (Prev. 54.4)
- Chinese Composite PMI (Mar) 54.0 (Prev. 52.9)

subject: PRE-MARKET TAIWAN AND SINGAPORE STOCK NEWS: Hon Hai (2317 TT) FY net declined for the 1st time since 2008 but still topped estimates
content:
TAIWAN

Hon Hai (2317 TT)
- Co. FY net declined for the 1st time since 2008 in which it fell 6.7% Y/Y to TWD 138.7bln vs. Exp. TWD 129.4bln, oper. profit TWD 112.6bln vs. Exp. TWD 149.7bln. (Newswires)

Other News
- Taiwan’s electronics makers are said to face a trifecta of headwinds from increased costs, lower iPhone sales and trade tensions. (Nikkei)

 

SINGAPORE

Noble (NOBL SP)
- Co. major shareholder Goldilocks highlighted serious inaccuracies and deficiencies of Noble’s reply to the SGX regarding the restructuring support agreement, in which it noted that liquidation was not the only alternative to the restructuring and that management should not be allowed to obtain free equity and full release from liability. (Straits Times)

Sembcorp Industries (SCI IS)
- Co. CEO and other top executives are taking a voluntary pay reduction of between 10%-15%. (Straits Times)
